qas.question: What is the primary use of Compact Disc + Graphics?

answers.text: to display lyrics on a television set for karaoke

qas.question: How is graphics information read from a CD+ Graphics?

answers.text: television set or a computer monitor

qas.question: Which channels does the CD+G use to hold graphics data?

plausible_answers.text: it can output a graphics signal

qas.question: Why can a CD+G not play on an audio CD player?
How many bits does a normal CD use?

plausible_answers.text: hooked up to a television set or a computer monitor

qas.question: Why are CD-G players not useful for karaoke?
What channels does a normal CD use?

context: Compact Disc + Graphics is a special audio compact disc that contains graphics data in addition to the audio data on the disc. The disc can be played on a regular audio CD player, but when played on a special CD+G player, <b3_0>it can output a graphics signal<b3_0/> (typically, the CD+G player is <b5_0>hooked up to a <a1_0>television set or a computer monitor<b5_0/><a1_0/>); these graphics are almost exclusively used <a0_0>to display lyrics on a television set for karaoke<a0_0/> performers to sing along with. The CD+G format takes advantage of the <a2_0>channels <b6_0>R through W<b6_0/><a2_0/>. These <b4_0>six<b4_0/> bits store the graphics information.
